H0.text: Deterministic equations are the two simplest models of population growth that describe the rate of change in the size of a population over time.

H1.text: Predestination equations are the two simplest models of population growth used to describe the rate of change in the size of a population over time.

H2.text: Analogous equations are used by the two simplest models of population growth to describe the rate of change in the size of a population over time.

H3.text: Wave function is what the two simplest models of population growth use to describe the rate of change in the size of a population over time.

A4.text: Most populations do not grow exponentially, rather they follow a logistic model.

A5.text: The growth of a population can often be modelled by the logistic equation dP/dt = rP(1−P/K).

A6.text: The solution to the equation is P(t)=K/(1+((K-P0)/P0)e^{-rt})

A10.text: The relationship between a system's wave function and the observable properties of the system appears to be non-deterministic.

A11.text: Rate of change (mathematics), either average rate of change or instantaneous rate of change
